title: Bank of America projects ‘robust' interest income growth as loans rebound
text:
Bank of America said its annual profit reached an all-time high in 2021 and gave a bullish outlook for the year to come in anticipation of multiple interest rate increases by the Federal Reserve and a revival in lending.

Quarterly profit at the second-largest US bank by assets jumped 28 per cent to $7bn as both its wealth management and investment banking divisions reported record revenues.

Most large US banks have struggled to grow their revenue from their core business of making loans after the Fed dropped interest rates to rock-bottom levels and cash infusions from stimulus programmes left many consumers and companies with little need to borrow.

However, BofA registered double-digit increases in net-interest income for a second consecutive quarter by investing deposits in debt securities at a faster pace than its megabank peers. Net-interest income rose 11 per cent to $11.4bn in the fourth quarter, while average loan balances across the bank inched 1 per cent higher.

With investors now pricing in four interest rate rises this year and loan growth starting to accelerate, BofA expects “robust” net-interest income growth for the year, said Alastair Borthwick, chief financial officer, on a call with journalists.

Excluding loans from the government-backed Paycheck Protection Program, year-end loan balances were 8 per cent higher at $974bn.

“I'd say we're pretty optimistic on loan growth,” Borthwick said. “Probably more optimistic than we might be at the beginning of a normal year pre-pandemic.”

BofA also plans to hold its 2022 expenses at 2021 levels in contrast to rivals that warned shareholders of higher expenses when they reported earnings earlier this month.

Wall Street giants JPMorgan Chase and Goldman Sachs both reported double-digit increases in expenses and warned 2022 spending would likely be even higher to keep up with wage inflation and fintech competitors.

Brian Moynihan, BofA's chief executive, has spent most of the past decade slashing costs at the bank while earmarking at least $3bn a year for new technology projects. The strategy has helped the bank roll out industry-leading technology such as its chatbot, Erica, while expenses have fallen roughly $20bn since he unveiled his cost-cutting plan in 2011.

The bank said it planned to keep its annual technology development budget steady at about $3.5bn. “I feel like the results of our technology investments are there for people to see,” Borthwick said.

Fourth-quarter expenses rose 6 per cent to $14.7bn compared with last year, driven by higher performance-based pay in its investment bank and wealth management divisions.

Investment banking fees jumped 26 per cent from a year ago to $2.4bn, and wealth management revenue rose 16 per cent to $5.4bn as clients invested an additional $491bn with the bank.

BofA reported overall earnings of 82 cents a share, up from 59 cents a share a year earlier. Revenue jumped 10 per cent to $22.1bn. Analysts polled by FactSet had forecast earnings of 77 cents on $22.18bn in revenue.
